Each divinity wields a personal weapon of medieval fashion, like for instance an imposing sword, a bow, a dreadful halberd. Victory goes to who prevails in 2 out of 3 rounds (the duration of each of which is 60 seconds), and a bonus score related with time and energy left is given to them. Slight gameplay alterations distinguish the Saturn game version.
title: Ragnagard

description: Need for Speed: Rivals is an open world racing game and the 20th installment in this series. Like Need for Speed: Hot Pursuit it supports two storylines: The Racer and The Cop (with three separate paths: patrol, enforcer, or undercover). Both have a full career progression, through speedlists for the racer and assignments for the cop. Players level up by completing objectives. There are gadgets such as an EMPs, shockwaves and the ability to call in roadblocks that can be upgraded. The game takes place in the fictional location Redview County. It is an open world with 160 km (100 miles) of streets. The game still incorporates the Autolog system and introduces AllDrive, which allows the player to seamlessly transition from the single-player game to online multiplayer, both cooperatively and head-to-head.
title: Need for Speed: Rivals

description:
Haunted Castle is a 2D arcade platform game, part of the Castlevania game universe. It's the first game in the series for arcade machines.

The game's main hero is once again Simon Belmont. He wants to rescue his wife Selena from Dracula. The gameplay is simple - Simon goes from left to right and fights against various enemies - skeletons, zombies, bats, and others. 

Belmont has his trusty whip and can carry one sub-weapon, like bombs. Hearts are ammo, required to use any type of sub-weapon The game has 6 levels, every one ending with a boss fight.
title: Haunted Castle

description: Basement Crawl is a multiplayer game similar to Bomberman. The players take on the role of macabre toys, visiting places such as creepy carnivals or butcher shops, and try to gain score by blowing each other up with traps in grid-based, maze-like arenas. The players can lay down traps that explode in straight lines in four directions. The characters are also able to kick the traps out of their way. Power-ups sometimes appear, such as more powerful traps, landmines, and traps which can be detonated remotely. There are four characters to choose from, each of which has slightly different stats. Each round lasts for a limited time, and - depending on the game mode (deathmatch or team deathmatch) - the winner is the player or the team with the highest score.
title: Basement Crawl

description: Prehistoric Isle 2 is a 2D side scrolling shooter with dinosaurs. It's a continuation of the SNK shooter franchise started with PREHISTORIC ISLE in 1930. The player controls a helicopter and must shoot dangerous dinosaurs in a city. The game is a pretty standard, dynamic shmup - the player flies forward, kills various enemies, gathers power-ups, and sometimes, rescues people. The game uses a similar pre-rendered graphic style to Pulstar.
title: Prehistoric Isle 2

description:
Samurai foxes have stolen the sacred acorns that belong to your clan. You are a ninja squirrel, tasked with responsibility to recover them. In Nutjitsu you take control of a ninja Squirrel, and navigate around a map crawling with samurai fox guards. Acorns periodically spawn around the map with different point values depending on their color and rarity. Collect as many acorns as possible before being caught to earn better rewards and higher scores. Each mission completed awards acoins. The acoins can be spent on power-ups such as speed boosts, decoys, smoke bombs, enemy freezing spells and one that will disintegrate any enemy it touches. In addition to the standard collect-all-you-can mode, there are several objective modes with interesting gameplay twists: lurker, collect scrolls, collect and deliver, collect a number, and collect a color. Each of these objectives can be played at varying difficulties ranging from very easy to extremely difficult.
  • Lurker is a king-of-the-hill mode in which magic areas spawn around the map. Stand in a zone to tick off time toward your objective. Each zone will move after a certain time has been scored in it.

  • In collect scrolls, scrolls appear around the map that will quickly disappear if not collected. There is a target number that, once gathered, will end the round in victory.

  • Collect and deliver has a sack on the map that is a delivery point for collected acorns. Up to eight acorns can be gathered before making a delivery. Once again, reaching the target number results in victory.

  • Collect a number is a slight variation of standard gameplay in that the player simply has to collect a specific number of acorns in any fashion to achieve victory.

  • Collect a color presents a specific color of acorn that must be collected. This color changes on a timer throughout the round. All colors can be collected for points but only acorns of the active color are counted toward the round's objective. Once meeting the objective number, the round is complete.
title: Nutjitsu

description: Crimsonland is an enhanced version of the 2003 game Crimsonland. It is a top-down arcade arena shooter that is similar in design to the original game. The player controls a character that needs to survive in an arena against wave of enemies. Just like the original game there are various weapons and power-ups, but with an overhaul for the visual style. There are two main game modes: Quests and Survival. Quests consists of six sets of ten levels that need to be completed one by one to progress. They have a fixed ending reached when a progression bar near the top is completely filled. By killing monsters the character gains experience and eventually unlocks about 30 weapons and 55 perks. There are three difficulty levels. Survival consists of five separate modes (Survival, Rush, Blitz, Weapon Picker, and Nukefism) each with their own rules for weapons and perks. Some start with an assault rifle, others let you pick weapons and perks at the beginning or after leveling up, or offer limited ammo, etc. In each of these modes the goal is to survive as long as possible without an ending. The arenas are always slightly larger than a single-screen environment and enemies appear from all directions. The character can be moved around and can also shoot in any direction. The cross-hair counts down the remaining ammo and then the weapon needs to be reloaded. A blue circle surrounding the character shows the remaining health. Various power-ups and weapons can be picked up by destroying enemies, but only one weapon can be carried at all times. There are also bomb power-ups that destroy all enemies in the vicinity The game has online leaderboards and supports four-player cooperative games in a local multiplayer mode.

sample_screenshots.caption:
The Main Menu
A battle rages in the background

The start of a game
There are six quests and each quest has ten levels

The start of a game
There are six quests and each quest has ten levels

title: Crimsonland

description: Q*bert: Rebooted combines the original Q*bert arcade game (Classic) with a Rebooted version. The original version is identical to the initial arcade game. Players guide the character Q*bert as he needs to change all tiles on an isometric cube pyramid to a target colour to complete levels. Tiles are connected and have a maximum of four directions to hop to a new one. Each tile he lands on changes colour. Early stages have a limited amount of colours, but later ones require multiple hops to get the correct colour. Meanwhile he needs to dodge enemies (Coily, Ugg, Slick, Sam, Wrong Way and Red Ball) that also move around. There are also falling balls to avoid. Enemies can be lured off the pyramid by jumping on a floating disc near the side of the pyramid, causing them to fall off while Q*bert re-appears on the other side. The Rebooted 3D game mode changes the tiles from squares to hexagons, offering six points of directions to move instead of the classic four. It also has a modern visual style with crisp graphics and smooth colours. This mode introduces thirty levels, seven new playable characters (Q*zard, Q*bertha, Q*bot, Q*zilla, Q*tee, Q*knight and Q*nicorn) and three new enemies (Homer, Uppercut and Treasure Chest). Completing levels in this mode is not enough to advance. It uses a three-star rating system where more than one star is needed to keep unlocking new levels. A star is awarded for completing a level, reaching a certain high score, and not exceeding the time limit. After each completed level a bonus level is played to earn gems. These are used to unlock the new characters, which differ only cosmetically. There are also various power-ups and traps. The later released Xbox One version has five additional playable characters and a new soundtrack by EnV.

sample_screenshots.caption: Choose between the Classic and the Rebooted version. As Q*Bert hops between the divider, his look changes to fit the version.
Start of the first level (Classic mode)

title: Q*bert: Rebooted

description: Yōjūden is a 2D top-down fantasy shooter, similar to Commando or Ninja Princess in an ancient land. The player controls a small, bearded man who wears a horned helmet, goes straight forward and shoots various enemies and bosses. He has unlimited bullets, but the weapon has a very limited range.
title: Yōjūden

description: 1001 Spikes is a difficult platformer designed with the retro aesthetics of an 8-bit game. It is an enhanced version of Aban Hawkins & 1000 Spikes. It was remade entirely with an improved visual style, more than twice the levels, redesigned levels, additional modes and additional characters. The protagonist is Aban Hawkins who explores different environment in search for his father, the archeaologist Jim Hawkins, and the treasure of Poko-Mum rumoured to be behind a golden door. He travels through Antarctica and South America with locations such as jungle, caverns and lava temples. The title references the amount of lives the player has to complete the game. These are needed to complete the hard levels filled with enemies and traps such as spikes, boulders, falling platforms, crushing blocks, etc. – requiring a lot of trial and error. Basic controls consist of movement, a regular and a high jump, and an attack move (both melee and ranged). It is also possible to talk to characters at certain moments. A large amount of characters and additional costumes can be unlocked throughout the game, usually by discovering gold skulls in levels. Certain characters have specific abilities. The character Ninja Aban for instance is able to brief hold on to walls and perform a wall jump, Tina Hawkins (his sister) can cling to walls, and President Thompson has a double jump. Other characters are variants of Aban such as Soldier Aban and Slayer Aban (a nod to Castlevania), or characters from indie games such as Meat Boy (Super Meat Boy), Nyx (NyxQuest: Kindred Spirits), Curly Brace (Cave Story), Commander Video (Bit.Trip) and a large amount from Super Time Force. There are also references to classic games such as Ghost 'N Goblins' Sir Arthur's white armour, Nathan Drake (Uncharted) for the PlayStation version and Mr. Video Game (Mario) for the Wii U and 3DS version. Each character has its own story elements, but cannot be swapped on the fly or between levels; they each have their full campaign. Spikes are the common hazard to avoid and most levels have a key required to open the door that leads to the next level. For the first part of the game players have the ability to skip certain levels, but this locks off the second part of the campaign where this is disabled. That means that to complete the entire game, eventually all levels need to be completed, but it is possible to access a world map and return to any of them. The story mode contains 61 levels and the entire games has more than 100 levels. The game can locally be played cooperatively with up to four players and also in a versus mode. Next to the main story mode there are three arcade modes called The Golden Vase, Tower of Nannar, and The Lost Levels. The first is the versus mode where players fight each other to beat coins out of vase. These coins, also found in the story mode, can be spent in a shop for unlockables. The other two are additional campaigns for solo or cooperative play. The Vita and 3DS versions lack the arcade modes and multiplayer.
title: Aban Hawkins & the 1001 Spikes: The Temple of the Dead Mourns the Living

description: Soldier Girl Amazon is a 2D top-down shooter, similar to Commando, Ikari Warriors and many other shooters. Main heroine is the Mighty Fighting Amazon - a female warrior with a shield, who can shoot energy blasts from her magic sword. Gameplay is very simple and straightforward: she walks forward and shoots enemies. The player can also find a special motorbike, a vehicle that is fast and gives and gives additional defense. The games has eight territories.
title: Soldier Girl Amazon

description: Crazy Climber 2 is the sequel to the 1980 arcade game Crazy Climber. While sporting updated graphics the gameplay remains mostly identical to that of its predecessor: using two joysticks, the player needs to climb up the face of high-rise buildings, avoiding closing windows, falling objects, cranes, birds, laundry, gorillas, etc. In some spots, there will be a girl leaning out of a window, if the player gets to her, they will receive a kiss and bonus points. Reach the top of the building and catch a ride on a helicopter over to the next building. The game consists of six levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: "Night mission - a beauty aid for skin of bust and body!"
Hey man, do you mind!? I'm trying to hook up with this girl here and you're throwing a TV at me...

title: Crazy Climber 2

description: This version of Gem Smashers is a remake of the 2003 Game Boy Advance game with the same name. The gameplay stays the same as the original with the player controlling little creatures that bounce around single screen levels with the aim of smashing gems. The gems are of various colours and therefore it's necessary to change the creature to the corresponding colour by hitting specific colour changing blocks. The player also has to avoid the skull blocks that kill the player upon contact. The most noticeable difference from the original is the new look with three dimensional graphics. Some minor differences in gameplay exist too. For instance there are no lives so the player can continue playing no matter how many skulls he touches. The remake consists of the same story mode as the original game as well as a battle mode for two players but lacks the arcade mode from the Game Boy Advance version. New is a tutorial as well as extra special content that can be unlocked by progressing through the story mode. On Nintendo 3DS there is one exclusive mode, Color-Cade, which consists of 30 small and fast paced levels where the player rotates around a pillar while destroying rocks.
title: Gem Smashers

description: Stakes Winner 2 is a horse-racing game and the sequel to Stakes Winner. The player can choose from 12 different horses with different statistics to race with. Races consist of 8 horses. Rival horses can't be chosen. Between races, there are bonus training games that can be used to boost your horse's abilities. Prize money can be used to buy items from the stable shop, to be used during races.
title: Stakes Winner 2

description: Fever SOS is a 2D arcade vertical scrolling space shooter in danmaku/bullet hell style. The player chooses one from 3 fighters and 1 from 3 types of "Powerful shot" (available by pressing the shoot button), and ship's speed. Gameplay is pretty typical (fly forward / shoot enemies / collect items / destroy bosses), but the player can capture "disco-man" - people, who are dropping from destroyed ships, required for scoring. The game has non-typical music for a shoot'em up - disco!
title: Fever SOS

description: Geometry Wars 3: Dimensions is the fourth game in the arcade shooter series. It is made by a new developer, but with a large group of people who were involved with the previous games. The biggest novelty is the introduction of 3D environments, sometimes only aesthetically in actually flat environments, but also with complete 3D levels where the ship moves around a cube or globe in any direction. The main game mode is called Adventure. It offers a level path with additional levels unlocked gradually and different game modes such as Boss (defeat the boss before time expires), Checkpoint (clear waves for extra time to reach the target score), Deadline (reach the target score before time runs out), Evolved (reach the target score with only three lives) and Titan (reach the target score with only one life). Each level has three targets based on performance to earn stars and these are required to keep unlocking new levels. In the boss mode for instance defeating the boss as quickly as possible is not sufficient, you need to get many kills in the provided time to reach a high score as well. The gameplay is similar to the previous games. The player controls a space ship with unlimited ammo that can be moved in any direction in a small arena. As in a twin stick shooter the ship can also shoot in any direction regardless of movement. Generally the goal is to survive as long as possible clearing waves of enemies. Defeated enemies leave behind green geoms that add to a score multiplier when collected. Sometimes a small group of objects spawns. When destroyed, a better default weapon is provided for a short time, such as rapid fire, more bullets or bullets that travel to different directions at once. Also returning is a limited amount of bombs that clear the entire screen, but without providing points. Entirely new to the series is a companion drone. By defeating bosses different drones are unlocked and a currency is earned by completing levels to upgrade them multiple times. The available drones are Attack, Collect, Defend, Ram, Snipe. They are controlled by the CPU and stay close to the player's ship, providing assistance in various ways. Next to bombs, five supers can be unlocked as additional weapons with limited ammo. They cover parts of the grid in small explosives, fire homing missiles, create a defensive black hole etc. Before starting a game one drone and one super can be selected. The game modes of the previous games, available as single sessions, are available in a separate Classic mode. They are Deadline Classic, Evolved Classic, King Classic (no guns outside king zones), Pacifism Classic (no guns, move through barriers to destroy nearby enemies), and Waves Classic. There are competitive game modes, both offline (up to four players) and online (up to eight players). In the Stock mode the first team to kill the boss wins. When time runs out instead, the team with the highest score wins. Personal ammo is limited to 50 bullets. Players need to collect ammo packets to gain more bullets and these can be shared between the team players. In the Summoner game mode the team with the highest score wins when time runs out. In this mode the ships need to shoot towers to spawn enemies the team can kill to receive points. The other team also attempts to claim towers however to have enemies spawn for them. In both game modes the multiplier is shared between all team members and if one member dies it is reset for everyone. In March 2015 a free update was provided that renamed the game Geometry Wars 3: Dimensions - Evolved. It includes a new Ultimate mode with new levels, new game modes and grid shapes, a new sweep drone and detonator super, eight new enemy types, a new Hardcore mode with no drones allowed, Retro Evolved Classic as a new game type in the Classic mode, and a number of tweaks to the gameplay.

sample_screenshots.caption: The title screen after the March 2015 update with a title change.
You see the game mode and targets before starting a game in the Adventure mode.

title: Geometry Wars 3: Dimensions - Evolved

description: BlazeRush is an arcade racing game similar to Rock 'n Roll Racing. Races take place on short tracks with the camera positioned in a fixed, isometric-like view next to the track. As the camera stays fixed relative to the car, the controls need to be adjusted based on the position on the track. The game is set on three planets with sixteen tracks in total. During races there is no health; when knocked off the track the car automatically respawns. All racers are kept in view at all times. When one car lags behind it eventually respawns closer to the other racers. In the career mode races need to be completed based on different game modes. There are regular circuit races, time trials, death races and king races. In death races races the cars are chased by a giant spiked steamroller. Every now and then it approaches, destroying all cars in the way until only one remains. Points are then awarded based on the position and there are multiple sessions until a survivor race is completed. When knocked off the track in a survivor race, the car does not respawn until the next session. King races are won by staying in the lead longer than the other racers, regardless of the ending position. By winning races points, cups and medals are earned. Cups are objectives specific for each track. By doing well additional tracks and racers are unlocked. Each racer has different statistics based on mass, acceleration and handleability. Slow cars have little acceleration, but are not affected much by projectiles. Fast cars have great acceleration, but are easily knocked off the track. There are also racers that slightly hover above the track. While racing various pick-ups spawn. There is a boost that can be activated by the player, either as a regular boost or different types of strong ones that can also easily catapult a car into the void. Weapon pick-ups include an autogun, a seeking missile, a chainsaw blade, a slime shot that slows down and a soundwave. As opponents cannot be destroyed permanently (except for survivor races), the main goal is to use weapons to knock opponents off the tracks and gain the lead. There is also a focus on drifting through corner and avoiding obstacles and the track borders. The game supports multiplayer for up to four players offline and eight players online.

sample_screenshots.caption: In the early races the objectives and mechanics are explained.
When knocked off the track, a boost brings you back.

title: BlazeRush

description: Pix the Cat is a fast-paced game set in mazes using elements from Pac-Man and Snake. The protagonist is Pix the Cat, a character previously introduced in the game PIXEL! The game contains four different game modes. The main arcade mode consists of three environments (starter, main, dessert) unlocked gradually. The goal is to reach a high score with a limited amount of time. Pix moves at a constant speed and can be moved in any of four directions as long as there is no obstacle in the way. A single field contains eggs and marked spots. He needs to collect the eggs Pac-Man-style, which causes them to hatch as ducklings that trail behind him, similar to the tail in Snake. To get rid of them and to score he needs to bring them to the marked spots by moving over them, with a duckling removed for each spot. To achieve a large score different types of mechanics are combined. A combo meter is filled up with up to four tiers (x2, x5, x10 and frenzy) as long as Pix does not run into walls, obstacles or his own trail of ducklings. When he gets stuck he immediately respawns, but the ducklings are lost as well as a part of the combo meter. The combo meter is also reduced if he releases ducklings on spots before all the eggs in a single area are collected, which causes them to crack, but the area can still be completed. An area can also be cleared perfectly for a larger score. When he approaches a wall or is about to get stuck the game slows down, shows escape route arrows and zooms in similar to the way it is done in Pac-Man: Championship Edition DX and he can also grind walls like in that game to quickly turn when it is possible. As the combo meter increases, the game's speed increases as well, making it possible to complete more of the game in the allotted time. In the highest combo tier called frenzy, skull enemies which otherwise harm Pix can be defeated similar to taking a power pill in Pac-Man, by headbutting them, for a large amount of points. Each combo tier introduces a different visual style. Each of the three worlds has a small amount of randomization for the environments, making sessions similar, but never entirely identical. After clearing an entire area an exit appears to go deeper into the maze and both the previous and the next part of the game are often kept in view, similar to the way it is done in Jumpman. It is also always possible to return to a previous maze through an exit, but new exits only appear when an area is completed. The game is not always shown in the same size, sometimes the previous maze is kept in view and the next one is shown as a very small environment next to it, with dynamic zoom. By reaching certain scores additional worlds are unlocked including a random daily arcade grid, as well as new companion voices and artwork. The second game mode is called Laboratory. Here Pix needs to collect cells and deliver them similar to the Arcade mode. Pix no longer moves at a constant speed, but slides in a certain direction until an obstacle is encountered. It is more of a puzzle mode where the player is encouraged to complete a maze with a certain amount of moves to receive a bonus. It is stricter than the Arcade mode, as all cells need to be collected first before they are delivered or the level is failed immediately. Later levels introduce moving enemies that need to be avoided. The third game mode is shown in black-and-white and is called Nostalgia. With a visual design of those of silent films and early animation movies, it is a kind of survival mode. Pix collects eggs with a trail of ducklings similar to the Arcade mode, but does not need to deliver them. Instead he needs to collect a certain amount of eggs that keep spawning without getting stuck or running into enemies. Later levels become more complex, for instance having three different mazes with three cats controlled simultaneously. A bonus is provided for completing levels quickly. The fourth game mode is a local multiplayer mode called Arena (not available on Vita). Up to four players control a Pixbot character on a single screen, but often with multiple mazes, grabbing eggs to create a trail. They need to ram each other and can use power-up eggs to receive a speed boost or shoot a projectile to stun another character or put down a mine. The more eggs in the trail, the slower a Pixbot moves. The goal is to become the last Pixbot standing. With three or more players in a game, knocked out players turn into ghosts that can still slowly move around the area. If a ghost manages to hit an active Pixbot, the ghost player is revived as a Pixbot and can continue playing.

sample_screenshots.caption: All the ducks in a row, now you just need to deliver them.

title: Pix the Cat

description: Mat Mania is a wrestling game and the spiritual successor to Tag-Team Wrestling. The player controls a wrestler in a televised event broadcast by the fictional T.W.A. (Taito Wrestling Association in the US version, Technos Wrestling Association in the Japanese version). The wrestler needs to compete against five opponents in a fixed order: Insane Warrior (US) / Insane Worrier (Japan), Karate Fighter, Coco Savage, The Pirania and Golden Hulk (US) / Blues Bloody (Japan). When the five fights are completed successfully a champion belt is presented in a ceremony and then the five fighters needed to be defeated again, but then drawn in a random order. The fighter can be moved in eight directions and only two actions are used to kick and punch. Pressing both buttons simultaneously makes the character run. Based on the position in the ring it is possible to sprint and launch from the ropes, pin a wrestler, get on the ropes, throw a wrestler out of the ring, perform ring jump attacks, holds, grabs, a should block, a headlock, an Irish wisp, a body slam, a piledriver, a vertical suplex, a back body drop, an elbow smash, a clothesline, a jumping kick, a body splash, a sunset flip and a knee drop, and throw the opponent into the environment, also out of the ring. Various celebrities and comic book characters make cameos as part of the spectator crowd. The game supports two players taking turns. For the Sharp X68000 platform the game is available only in the compilation Video Game Anthology Vol. 8: Exciting Hour / Shusse Ōzumō.
